For the simultaneous attainment of the utilization of renewable biomass resources and the mitigation of greenhouse effects, it is very promising to develop a green, recyclable, and highly efficient heterogeneous catalyst for the synthesis of cyclic carbonates by CO2 cycloaddition reaction with epoxides. Herein, novel cellulose nanofibers (CNF) supported (Salen)Cr(Ⅲ) complex was effectively synthesized for the aforementioned reaction. The cellulose nanofibers (CNF) were firstly modified with (3-aminopropyl) triethoxysilane (APTES), and then its Schiff base with salicylaldehyde was synthesized, which further subjected to coordination treatment with chromium chloride to form a novel heterogeneous catalyst, labelled as CNF-(Salen)Cr(Ⅲ). The catalytic performance of the catalysts shown that CNF-(Salen)Cr(Ⅲ) and co-catalyst TBAB can synergistically catalyze the cycloaddition of CO2 with epichlorohydrin (ECH) at mild reaction conditions, and the yield of chloropropene carbonate (CPC) reached up to 97.8% with high selectivity. The CNF-(Salen)Cr(Ⅲ) complex maintained high catalytic activity after six cycles of repeated runs and has acceptable catalytic effect on other series of epoxies. Based on density functional theory (DFT) calculations, a reaction mechanism including adsorption activation of epoxides, epoxides ring opening, CO2 insertion, and the formation of cyclic carbonate, was proposed for the CNF-(Salen)Cr(Ⅲ) complex catalyzed cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxides. Graphical abstract Cellulose nanofibers (CNF) supported (Salen)Cr(Ⅲ) composite as a novel heterogeneous catalyst (CNF-(Salen)Cr(Ⅲ)), which has good catalytic activity for CO2 cycloaddition, and DFT calculation further revealed the reaction mechanism. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Cellulose nanofibers (CNFs) Salen-type catalyst Heterogeneous catalysis CO2 cycloaddition Density functional theory calculations Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction With the massive consumption of fossil fuels-based energy and the increasing seriousness of various environmental problems, the utilization of carbon dioxide (CO2) has become a hot spot of continuous research [1–3]. The chemical conversion of CO2 has not only mitigate the environmental problems such as global warming and seawater acidification caused by its massive emissions, but also results in the production of highly value-added chemicals such as cyclic carbonates [4,5], dimethyl carbonates [6,7], carbamates [8,9], oxazolidinone [10,11] and so on. Among these, the cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxides to prepare cyclic carbonates has the advantages of relatively low raw material cost, high atomic utilization rate and the formation of less by-products. Cyclic carbonates are important class of chemicals in the aforesaid list, which are widely used in various industries. It found promising role as non-protonic solvents [12], as the electrolyte of batteries [13], as monomers of synthetic polyester [14], and as intermediates of organic synthesis in pharmaceutical industries [15]. Due to the high thermodynamic stability and kinetic inertia of CO2, the cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxides usually necessitates the presence of catalysts [16]. Currently, several types of catalysts have been reported for the CO2 cycloaddition with epoxides, including ionic liquids [17,18], Salen metal complexes ((Salen)M) [19–21]. Metal Organic Frameworks (MOFs) [22,23], Porous Organic Polymers (POPs) [24,25]. Among these catalysts, the (Salen)M catalysts have been widely used in the synthesis of cyclic carbonates by catalytic reaction of CO2 with epoxides because of their adjustable structure, simple preparation, and high catalytic efficiency. However, the (Salen)M catalysts are difficult to be recovered and reused because of their homogenous nature, after completing reaction, which not only causes waste of catalyst, but also causes environmental pollution [26]. In order to solve this problem, the homogeneous (Salen)M catalysts were reported to be immobilized on heterogeneous supports [27]. Biswas et al. [28] synthesized a heterogeneous [PS-Zn(II)L] catalyst with good recyclability using modified chloromethylated polystyrene as a catalyst support. Ghabdian et al. [29] immobilized Salen Cu(II) complex on graphene oxide (GO) nanosheets by the linkage of 3-chloropropyltrimethoxysilylamine and Cu(II)Salen@GO catalyst was resulted. Liu et al. [30] synthesized a series of heterogeneous catalysts with SBA-15 as a support material, in which SBA was grafted with different metal complexes by the quaternization reaction. Previously our research group [26] had immobilized Co(III)-Salen complexes on Fe3O4@SiO2 nanoparticles prepared by the reverse microemulsion method to obtain a heterogeneous Fe3O4@SiO2@Co(III)-Salen catalyst. However, these catalysts were not only complicated to prepare, but also non-renewable and non-degradable in nature, which cannot achieve green and sustainable concept in catalysis. Therefore, the selection of a suitable support material is highly important in any catalytic reaction. It has been reported that the cellulose is widely distributed in nature and is considered to be one of the most abundant biomass resources with low cost and cheap availability. Cellulose is further pronounced for its excellent properties such as biodegradability, high mechanical strength, good thermal stability, and ease for its structural modification [31]. Therefore, it would be very attractive to develop renewable polymer material, cellulose as a natural green catalyst support. Moreover, the easy modification of cellulose provides the possibility to develop it as a catalyst support. In this article, a novel heterogeneous (Salen)M catalyst was prepared by immobilizing the (Salen)M complex on cellulose nanofibres (CNF) by a simple method. Specifically, the CNF was firstly modified with (3-aminopropyl) triethoxysilane (APTES) and subsequently loaded the (Salen)M complex to prepare heterogenous CNF-(Salen)Cr(Ⅲ) catalysts (Scheme 1 ). The characterization results of the prepared catalysts by FTIR, XPS and ICP-MS confirmed the successful synthesis of the CNF-(Salen)Cr(Ⅲ) catalyst. The effects of catalyst to epoxide ratio, reaction temperature, reaction time and initial CO2 pressure on the epoxide conversion, product selectivity and product yield were investigated in the catalytic CO2 cycloaddition reaction with epoxides. The CNF-(Salen)Cr(Ⅲ) showed high catalytic activity for different epoxides, and the yield of cyclic carbonate could reached more than 90% after six consecutive runs of reaction. A possible reaction mechanism was also proposed and further validated with density functional theory (DFT) calculations. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials The raw cellulose nanofibres (CNF) hydrogels with a consistency of 1.5% (w/w) was obtained from Tianjin Woodelf Biotechnology Co. Ltd. The TEMPO-mediated oxidation was used to produce CNF from hardwood bleached kraft pulp [32]. The carboxylate content of CNF was found to be 1.86 mmol/g, and the length and width were measured to be 0.2–2 μm and 10–20 nm, respectively. Chromium chloride, (3-aminopropyl) triethoxysilane (APTES), salicylaldehyde, epichlorohydrin (ECH), butylene oxide, propylene oxide, styrene oxide, cyclohexene oxide, glycidol, allyl glycidyl ether, glycidyl isopropyl ether, benzyl glycidyl ether, 1,2-epoxyhexane, chloroform-d (CDCl3), and tetrabutylammonium bromide (TBAB) were obtained from Aladdin Chemicals, China. The gases such as N2 (99.99%) and CO2 (99.99%) were purchased from Kunming Guangruida Gas Co., Ltd. The chemical reagents from purchased commercial sources were used directly. 2.2 Preparation of amino-functionalized CNF (CNF-NH2) In a typical procedure, 10 g of CNF hydrogel with a CNF content of 1.5% (w/w) and 20 mL of deionized water were added to a beaker and ultrasonically dispersed for 30 min to obtain a CNF suspension with a CNF content of 0.5% (w/w). Then 0.3 g of APTES was added into it, at room temperature and stirred for 3 h. Next the sample was kept for freeze-drying treatment for 24 h. After the liquid nitrogen freezing, the sample was further kept in an oven at 90 °C for 30 min to make the structure more stable after silane modification. The amino-functionalized cellulose nanofibers (CNF-NH2) were finally obtained by grinding the dried sample. The sample without APTES was also prepared by the same method and denoted as CNF-0. 2.3 Preparation of CNF supported Salen composites (CNF-Salen) Herein, 2 g CNF-NH2 sample was taken in a three-necked round bottom flask containing 40 mL anhydrous ethanol, which was placed in a constant temperature bath connected with a condenser and magnetic stirrer. When the temperature attained 80 °C in the solution, 2 mmol salicylaldehyde mixed with 10 mL ethanol was slowly added to it by drop by drop, and the reaction was continued for 12 h by continuous stirring. After the reaction, the formed yellow product was washed repeatedly with anhydrous ethanol until the filtrate was clear. Finally, CNF-Salen composite was obtained by vacuum drying at 60 °C for 12 h. 2.4 Preparation of CNF supported (Salen)Cr(Ⅲ) composites (CNF-(Salen)Cr(Ⅲ)) In this synthesis method, 0.1 g CNF-Salen sample was added to 25 mL tetrahydro furan (THF) taken in a three-necked flask and it was fixed on a magnetic stirrer with condenser. After N2 gas infused for 30 min, 0.2 g of anhydrous CrCl2 was quickly added into it, and again N2 was fed for 16 h, followed by normal stirring with air for 24 h. Since CrCl3 and THF will form Chromium(III) chloride tetrahydrofuran complex, the method of first coordination and then oxidation of CrCl2 is often adopted. After reaction, the obtained green product was repeatedly washed with absolute ethanol until the filtrate was completely clear. Finally, the CNF-(Salen)Cr(Ⅲ) catalyst was obtained by vacuum drying at 60 °C for 12 h. As a comparison, a homogeneous (Salen)Cr(III) catalyst was prepared, and the specific steps were as follows: Firstly, APTES (10 mmol, 1.9 mL) was dissolved in 50 ml of ethanol and poured into a 250 ml three-neck flask and heated to 80 °C. Then, salicylaldehyde (10 mmol, 1 mL) dissolved in 50 mL ethanol was slowly added dropwise into the flask and continued to reflux for 12 h and then cooled to room temperature. During this process, the solution turns yellow due to the reaction of the Schiff base to form an imine. Then CrCl2 (5 mmol, 0.61 g) was added, and after reacting for 12 h under N2 atmosphere, air was introduced to continue the reaction for 12 h. Finally, the obtained green solution was rotary evaporated to obtain the homogeneous (Salen)Cr(III) catalyst. 2.5 Materials characterization The Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra of the prepared samples were recorded on a Bruker Vertex 70 spectrometer in the wavenumber range of 4000–400 cm−1 with KBr pellets method. The thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was recorded by NETZSCH TG 209F3 thermal analyzer with a heating rate of 15 °C/min under pure nitrogen flow, in the temperature range of 20–1000 °C. The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was carried out in a Thermo-Fisher-ESCALAB 250Xi spectrometer with a monochromatic Al Kα radiation source. The 1H Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) spectra were recorded in the 600 MHz Bruker Avance III HD spectrometer with CDCl3 as solvent. The Cr content in the catalyst was determined by Agilent 5110, inductively coupled plasma (ICP) analyzer. The nitrogen content in the prepared catalyst was determined by using a Vario EL Ⅲ Organic element analyzer (EA). The morphological characteristics of the samples were investigated in a scanning electron microscope (SEM, TESCAN MIRA LMS), and the elemental composition and their distribution in the sample was obtained by energy dispersive x-ray spectroscopic and by elemental mapping methods respectively. 2.6 Catalytic activity of the prepared samples The catalytic activity of the prepared catalysts was evaluated in a high-pressure stainless-steel autoclave reactor for CO2 cycloaddition reaction. In a typical experiment, certain amount of catalyst, co-catalyst TBAB (catalyst: TBAB = 2:1 (w/w)) and 38 mmol epoxide (catalyst: epoxide = 1:125–1000 (molar ratio)) were added into a Teflon lined stainless steel autoclave with a capacity of 100 mL. Prior to the reaction, the sealed autoclave was purged three times with CO2 to remove other impurity gases. Next, CO2 pressure (0.5–2.5 MPa), reaction temperature (60–100 °C) and reaction time (0.5–6 h) were adjusted in the experiments as per the required reaction conditions. Once the reaction time was over, the temperature of the autoclave was cooled to room temperature using an ice bath, and the residual CO2 gas was slowly released. Finally, the reaction mixture was filtered, and the catalyst and the reaction products were collected separately. The products were then analyzed by 1H NMR spectrum, and the conversion, selectivity and yield were calculated according to the peak integration method reported in literature [33–35]. The catalyst left after each reaction was further washed with ethanol for few times and dried in a vacuum oven at 60 °C for reusability studies. 2.7 Computational studies The density functional theory (DFT) calculations were carried out in a Gaussian 09 computational package. By considering the fact that the active sites in CNF-(Salen)Cr(Ⅲ) catalyst are the metal centers, the smallest active unit (Salen)Cr(Ⅲ) was chosen as the computational model. The transition states and intermediates of cycloaddition reaction were calculated with the computational level of B3LYP/6-31+G (d, p)&&LANL2DZ. The minimum energy path (MEP) was constructed by the intrinsic reaction coordinate analysis (IRC) for the confirmation purpose. This method has been studied in detail by previous reports, and the calculation accuracy has been well proved [16,36]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of the prepared catalysts The FT-IR spectra of CNF-0, CNF-NH2, CNF-Salen and CNF-(Salen)Cr(Ⅲ) samples are shown in Fig. 1 (a). All the samples exhibited transmission bands at 3354, 2896 and 1609 cm−1, which belongs to the stretching mode vibration bands of hydroxyl groups in CNF, stretching mode vibration bands of C-H groups and the stretching vibration bands present in benzene ring skeleton respectively [37,38]. It shows that the chemical structure of CNF is not destroyed after chemical modification, which highlights its stability as a catalyst support. By comparing CNF-0 and CNF-NH2 samples, it was found that the infrared spectrum of CNF- NH2 has a sharp and well resolved transmission band at 1108 cm−1, which is attributed to the stretching vibration of C-O-Si bond. The formation of C-O-Si bond could be ascribed to the dehydration or condensation reaction between C-OH on CNF and Si-OH on APTES. It further indicates that the CNF was successfully amino-functionalized [26]. The results of organic element analysis showed that the content of N element in CNF-NH2 was 7.67%, which indirectly proved the successful synthesis of CNF-NH2 (Table S1). By comparing CNF-NH2 and CNF-Salen, it was found that CNF-Salen had an additional characteristic transmission band at 1636 cm−1. It accounts for the stretching mode vibration of C=N bond, formed by the dehydration reaction in the Schiff base formation, such as by the chemical reaction between -NH2 group on CNF-NH2 with C=O linkage in salicylaldehyde. Meanwhile, the stretching mode vibration bands of benzene ring skeleton and methylidyne (C-H) in salicylaldehyde were found to be appeared at 1495 cm−1 and 1464 cm−1 respectively, which further proves the successful synthesis of CNF-Salen [39]. By comparing the FTIR spectra of CNF-Salen and CNF-(Salen)Cr(Ⅲ), it was found that the transmission bands appearing at 698 cm−1 and 665 cm−1 in CNF-(Salen)Cr(Ⅲ) were corresponded to the double stretching vibrational bands of the Cr-N bond, indicating the successful coordination of the metal ion Cr with the Salen [40]. The results of ICP-MS further showed that the content of Cr element in CNF-(Salen)Cr(Ⅲ) was 3.41%, which indirectly evidenced the successful coordination of Cr (Table S4). Thus it is clear that the catalyst CNF-(Salen)Cr(Ⅲ) was prepared successfully. The thermal stability of CNF-0, CNF-NH2, CNF-Salen and CNF-(Salen)Cr(Ⅲ) samples was analyzed by thermal gravimetric analysis(TGA), and the results are shown in Fig. 1(b). As the temperature increasing from room temperature to 107 °C, the weight of the four samples decreased slightly, which is due to the mass loss caused by the separation of moisture or gas adsorbed on the material surface. The slight mass loss in the range from 107 °C to 222 °C could be produced by the separation of the bound water in the samples. In the temperature range of 222 °C to 352 °C, it was evident that the mass of CNF-0 decreased from 92% to 39%. It could be attributed to the degradation of its functional groups and the breakage of intermolecular hydrogen bonds in it. In addition, CNF-NH2, CNF-Salen and CNF-(Salen)Cr(Ⅲ) samples degraded continuously at 352 °C, and tended to be stable after 542 °C, which indicated that the grafted APTES can improve the thermal stability of the samples to a great extent. When the temperature increased to 1000 °C, the CNF-0 was completely carbonized and the residual mass was only 25%. However, the residual mass of CNF-NH2 and CNF-Salen samples was 41%, which could be due to the presence of Si in APTES, increasing the amount of residual carbon. Finally, the residual mass of the CNF-(Salen)Cr(Ⅲ) sample was observed to be 44%. It could be further due to the presence of residual Cr metal. Thus, it is very evident that the thermal degradation of four samples began after 222 °C, showing their favorable thermal stability for the CO2 cycloaddition reaction with epoxides. The chemical structure of CNF-(Salen)Cr(Ⅲ) catalyst was further characterized by XPS analysis. As shown in Fig. 2 (a), the peaks corresponding to C, N, O, Si, and Cr elements can be clearly observed in the wide scan XPS spectrum, which is consistent with the EDX mapping results. The deconvoluted Cr 2p XPS spectrum shown in Fig. 2(b) presented that the Cr in CNF-(Salen)Cr(Ⅲ) existing as its +3 oxidation state. The Cr 2p1/2 and Cr 2p3/2 peaks were found to be appeared at 585.8 eV and 576.2 eV respectively, which is highly consistent with the literature reports [41]. In Fig. 2(c), the deconvoluted peaks observed at the binding energies of 284.4 eV, 285.4 eV, 286.3 eV and 287.8 eV in the XPS spectrum of C 1 s could be attributed to the C-C/C=C, C-N, C-O and C=N linkages from CNF-(Salen)Cr(Ⅲ), respectively [4]. The narrow scan XPS spectra of N 1 s in CNF-(Salen)Cr(Ⅲ) presented in Fig. 2(d) had demonstrated that the peaks at the binding energies of 400.4 eV, 398.4 eV and 397.2 eV could be attributed to the presence of C-N, C=N and Cr-N bondings, respectively [42]. The peaks observed at the binding energies of 532.1 eV, 531.1 eV and 529.6 eV in XPS spectrum of O 1s (Fig. 2(e)) could be attributed to the existence of O-H, C-O, and Cr-O linkages in CNF-(Salen)Cr(Ⅲ), respectively [42]. The fitted XPS spectrum of Si 2p shown in Fig. 2(f) exhibited three deconvoluted peaks at the binding energies of 101.7 eV, 100.9 eV and 100.3 eV that could be ascribed to the presence of Si-O-Si, Si-O-C and Si-OH groups, respectively [43]. The surface morphology of the prepared CNF-0, CNF-NH2, CNF-Salen and CNF-(Salen)Cr(Ⅲ) samples were analyzed by SEM technique and the micrographs are shown in Fig. 3 . It can be seen from Fig. 3(a) that the unmodified CNF-0 pocesses a sheet-like structure with smooth surface without any porosity. However, after modification with APTES, the surface texture of CNF-NH2 was dramatically changed. The bigger sheets were observed to be cracked into smaller pieces and accumulated into a porous structure as evident in Fig. 3(b). After treated with salicylaldehyde, the surface texture of CNF-Salen was totally different from that of the corresponding raw material. The surface of the CNF-Salen was appeared to be highly porous with a number of micropores with different sizes and cave like appearance was noticed totally (Fig. 3(c)). The surface morphology of the CNF-(Salen)Cr(Ⅲ) was quite similar to that of CNF-Salen and no appreciable change in the surface texture was noticed after Cr coordination. The rough surface of CNF-Salen with high porosity was retained even after Cr modification (Fig. 3(d)). Moreover, the SEM elemental mapping results of the CNF-(Salen)Cr(Ⅲ) catalyst is presented in Fig. 3(e). It is obvious that the elements such as C, N, O, Si and Cr were uniformly distributed in the sample and it is worth to note that the uniform distribution of active center, Cr not only improves atomic availability but also enhances the catalytic activity [44]. 3.2 Catalytic activity of the prepared CNF-(Salen)Cr(Ⅲ) catalyst After characterizing the prepared samples, some preliminary experiments were firstly investigated, including the catalytic performance of samples and the effect of co-catalysts, and the results are shown in Table 1 . It can be seen that CNF-0, CNF-NH2, CNF-Salen and CNF-(Salen)Cr(Ⅲ) had no catalytic activity for the reaction when used alone (Table 1, entries 1–5). It could be attributed to the high energy barrier for the ring-opening of epoxies, which requires the synergistic action of co-catalyst to reduce the reaction energy barrier [16]. The co-catalyst TBAB exhibited certain catalytic activity for the cycloaddition reaction due to the nucleophilic ring-opening effect of Br anion (Table 1, entry 6) [45].However, a superior catalytic performance was observed when the co-catalyst TBAB was added to the prepared catalyst samples in the reaction mixture (Table 1, entries 7–11), which indicated a good synergistic effect between the catalyst and cocatalyst [46,47]. Before this, the effect of the ratio of catalyst and TBAB on the catalytic activity was examined. As shown in the Fig. S1, as the amount of TBAB increases, the catalytic activity increases significantly. When Catalyst/TBAB (w/w)=2:1, the yield of CPC can reach 97.8%. When the amount of co-catalyst TBAB continued to increase, the yield of CPC increased limitedly or even decreased. To reduce cost and avoid waste or pollution, Catalyst/TBAB (w/w)=2:1 is more suitable. It is worth mention that the CNF has a positive impact on catalyzing the cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxide, which is attributed to the presence of abundant hydroxyl groups in it [48]. Although the catalytic activity of homogeneous (Salen)Cr(Ⅲ) is slightly higher than that of heterogeneous CNF-(Salen)Cr(Ⅲ) due to its higher mass transfer efficiency. However, the separation is difficult, which will inevitably bring about problems such as production costs and environmental pressure. In contrast, CNF-(Salen)Cr(Ⅲ) will be more competitive in industrial production. To evaluate the catalytic performance of the CNF-(Salen)Cr(Ⅲ) catalyst for the cycloaddition of CO2 with ECH, the reaction parameters were varied and the effects of catalyst dosage, reaction temperature, duration of reaction (time), and reaction pressure on the selectivity and yield of chloropropene carbonate (CPC) were investigated in detail (Fig. 4 ). Fig. 4(a) shows the effect of catalyst to epoxide ratio on the reaction efficiency. As seen, with increasing the catalyst dosage, the yield of CPC increased as expected and the selectivity of CPC remained more than 95% in all of the studied catalyst to epoxide ratios. This could be attributed to the optimal availability active catalytic sites for the epoxide molecules. With the Cat. /ECH (mol/mol) ratio of 1/250, the yield of CPC has reached to 91.2%. When catalyst further increased to 2 times, i.e., (Cat./ECH (mol/mol) = 1/125), the yield of CPC has been increased slightly only. Therefore, by considering the utilization of the catalyst and its preparation cost, a Cat. /ECH (mol/mol) ratio of 1/250 was selected as the optimal ratio for next set of experiments. As shown in Fig. 4(b), the reaction temperature also had a great influence on the catalytic reaction. The higher reaction temperature not only provide the sufficient activation energy, but also activates the active metal center for the reaction and thus improving the catalytic activity. When the reaction temperature was increased from 60 °C to 100 °C, the yield of CPC increased from 52.9% to 98.1% with more than 95% product selectivity. The epoxide ECH was found to be completely reacted at 90 °C as there is no change was noticed in the product yield and selectivity by increasing the temperature by 10 °C. Therefore, from the perspective of saving energy and reducing costs, 90 °C was selected as the optimum reaction temperature. Fig. 4(c) shows the effect of reaction time on the catalytic efficiency. The yield of CPC reached 70.4% after 0.5 h of reaction, and the cycloaddition reaction reached the equilibrium state after 3 h of time on stream. Moreover, the product selectivity remained unchanged with the duration of reaction. Therefore, 3 h duration was chosen as the best reaction time in the following investigation of CO2 pressure. It can be seen from Fig. 4(d) that, when the CO2 pressure was lower than 1.5 MPa, the yield and the selectivity of CPC increased with an increase in CO2 pressure by 0.5 units. When the CO2 pressure was higher than 1.5 MPa, the results were observed to be in reverse order. This might be ascribed to the fact that the ECH near the catalyst would be diluted by the high concentration of CO2, resulting in an insufficient contact time between the ECH and the catalyst, thereby reducing the reaction efficiency as reported previously [49]. 3.3 Comparison of the catalytic performance with recent literature To highlight the effectiveness of the as-synthesized CNF-(Salen)Cr(Ⅲ) catalyst, it was compared with various excellent catalysts that has been reported in literature and the results are shown in Table 2 . It can be observed that at a reaction temperature 120 °C, most of the reported catalysts achieved good product yield, which not only reasons for the consumption of more energy and increases the process cost, but also brings safety and environmental concerns, as compared with 90 °C of CNF-(Salen)Cr(Ⅲ) catalyst (Table 2, Entries 1–6). Although there are some recently reported catalysts that were active at the reaction temperatures of 100 °C or 90 °C, they often require more reaction time to achieve high CPC yields, which undoubtedly reduces the production efficiency (Table 2, entries 7–9). However, the CNF-(Salen)Cr(Ⅲ)/TBAB catalytic system is found to be more competitive and it can achieve 97.8% CPC yield at relatively lower reaction temperature of 90 °C, lower initial CO2 pressure of 1.5 MPa and shorter reaction period of 3 h. The better catalytic performance of the prepared catalyst could be due to the following reasons: (1) CNF-(Salen)Cr(Ⅲ) is a nanocatalyst with high surface porosity, which increases the attachment sites for the active metal center Cr, and helps to improve the mass transfer rate and absorption efficiency of CO2, thus accelerating the reaction rate and improving the catalytic performance [50]. (2) There is a large number of hydroxyl (-OH) groups on the surface of CNF, which acts as hydrogen bond donor (HBD) to activate the epoxides and a synergistic catalyst with the active metal center, thus improving the catalytic efficiency [51,52]. Notably, compared with the previously reported catalysts for the cycloaddition of CO2, the catalyst reported in this study has not only the significant advantage of mild reaction conditions, but also is greener and more environmentally friendly. 3.4 Versatility and recyclability of the CNF-(Salen)Cr(Ⅲ) catalyst The catalytic performance of the CNF-(Salen)Cr(Ⅲ) for the cycloaddition of CO2 with different epoxides was further investigated (Table 3 ). As shown in Table 3, the CNF-(Salen)Cr(Ⅲ) catalyst had good catalytic activity for different epoxides. For less sterically hindered epoxides such as ECH and propylene oxide, only 3 h of reaction is required to obtain satisfactory yields of the corresponding cyclic carbonates (Table 3, entries 1–2). However, for larger sterically hindered epoxides, the catalytic efficiency is significantly reduced, and the reaction time of 3 h is obviously not enough (Table 3, entries 3–9). This is because the larger the substituent in the epoxide, the more activation energy is required to overcome the steric resistance, and thus the catalytic activity decreases. Fortunately, by prolonging the reaction time, satisfactory yields of the corresponding cyclic carbonates can be obtained even for larger sterically hindered epoxides. However, cyclohexane oxide was not converted to corresponding cyclic carbonate during the reaction of 12 h (Table 3, entry 10), which might be due to the structural effects of the inner ring and its high steric resistance as reported previously [61]. As a green and environmentally friendly catalyst, an important advantage of CNF-(Salen)Cr(Ⅲ) catalyst is that it can be easily separated from the reaction mixture and can be reused for next set of reactions. The yield of CPC was found to be more than 90%, even after six repeated cycles (Fig. 5 ). This could be ascribed to the presence of active metal center of the catalyst such as Cr ion, which is coordinated with O and N atoms of the Salen, through the coordination bonds that greatly enhances the stability of Cr ion and avoids the massive leaching phenomenon accounts for the reduction in catalytic activity. The inevitable mass loss per cycle and the leaching of a small amount of active sites Cr are the main reasons for the slight decrease in the catalytic activity. Thus, it can be concluded that the prepared CNF-(Salen)Cr(Ⅲ) catalyst has high catalytic activity, recycling performance, and structural stability, and also it is easy to separate and recover from the reaction mixture. 3.5 Plausible mechanism for CO2 cycloaddition with epoxides To understand the mechanism of CO2 cycloaddition with epoxides catalyzed by CNF-(Salen)Cr(Ⅲ), theoretical studies were conducted. By considering the convenience of theoretical calculation, (Salen)Cr(Ⅲ) structure as the active center was selected for the optimization purpose [30]. Based on our previous research [16,36], a reaction route for (Salen)Cr(Ⅲ) catalyzed CO2 cycloaddition was proposed. The mechanistic pathways and the relative Gibbs free energy diagram for the cycloaddition of CO2 with ECH are depicted in Fig. 6 and Fig. 7 respectively. Initially, the oxygen atom of epoxide, ECH interacts with the Cr atom of (Salen)Cr(Ⅲ), and an initial intermediate Int0 (8.08 kcal/mol) could be formed. At the same time, the C-O bond of ECH gets activated, and the β-C of ECH could be attacked by Br− to form a complex intermediate Int1 (23.62 kcal/mol). Immediately, this complex intermediate Int1 undergoes a ring-opening process to form a stable species of intermediate Int2 (19.92 kcal/mol). It could be occurred by the formation of an unstable transition state TS1 (46.59 kcal/mol). After the ring opening of epoxide, the CO2 molecule interacts with Int2 to form a stable trimolecular complex Int3 (24.68 kcal/mol). Subsequently, the CO2 molecule inserted into the resulting Cr-O bond to generate the intermediate Int4 (23.90 kcal/mol) through the transition state TS2 (28.96 kcal/mol). The intermediate Int4 then transformed into intermediate Int5 (27.78 kcal/mol) by undergoing an intramolecular ring-closing process with the concomitant elimination of Br−. During this stage, the Br-C bond was continuously stretched until it get cracked through the transition state TS3 (49.84 kcal/mol) and finally CPC could be formed with the regeneration of the catalyst. The calculation results show that the ring-closing of the formed cyclic carbonate was the rate-determining step in the process, and the required energy barrier is found to be 25.94 kcal/mol. The (Salen)Cr(Ⅲ) catalyst can provide an activation energy of 8.08 kcal/mol, which enables the ring-opening reaction to occur easily. Further, due to the presence of the co-catalyst Br−, the energy barrier of the epoxy ring-opening step was reduced from 46.59 kcal/mol to 22.97 kcal/mol. Due to the simple structure of (Salen)Cr(Ⅲ) with small steric hindrance effect, the insertion of CO2 becomes easy, and only an energy barrier of 4.28 kcal/mol needs to be overcome. In conclusion, CNF-(Salen)Cr(Ⅲ) showed satisfactory catalytic performance, recycling performance and structural stability by studying the structure morphology and catalytic performance. Further, based on DFT calculations and previous research [62,63], the possible mechanism of cycloaddition of CO2 and epoxide catalyzed by CNF-(Salen)Cr(Ⅲ) catalyst was proposed (Fig. 8 ). Firstly, the active center Cr atom on the CNF-(Salen)Cr(Ⅲ) catalyst is coordinated with the oxygen atom of the epoxide, and the epoxide is activated. Secondly, the nucleophile Br anion attacks the C atom of epoxide of β-C-O to complete the ring opening to form the β-C-Br intermediate. Next, the electrophilic C atom of CO2 is inserted by reacting with the negatively charged oxygen atom on the intermediate formed in the previous step, thus resulting in the formation of intermediate alkyl carbonate intermediates. Finally, cyclic carbonate is formed by intramolecular cyclization of intermediates. Meanwhile, both CNF-(Salen)Cr(Ⅲ) and Br anion will be regenerated for the next catalytic process. 4 Conclusions A heterogeneous CNF-(Salen)Cr(Ⅲ) catalyst with good catalytic performance was successfully synthesized and used for the synthesis of cyclic carbonates by CO2 cycloaddition reaction. Herein, (3-aminopropyl) triethoxysilane (APTES) was used as a linker to immobilize the (Salen)Cr(Ⅲ) complex on cellulose nanofibres (CNF) support. The results validated that the CNF is an excellent natural catalyst support and has a positive impact on catalyzing the cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxides. The catalytic performance results indicated that CNF-(Salen)Cr(Ⅲ)/TBAB exhibited a high product yield of 97.8% for the cycloaddition of CO2 with ECH under mild reaction conditions of 1.5 MPa CO2 pressure, a reaction temperature 90 °C and 3 h of reaction. Moreover, the CNF-(Salen)Cr(Ⅲ) catalyst was successfully recycled six times without any significant reduction in the catalytic efficiency, and also showed high activity for other series of epoxides. The DFT calculation studies further provided a theoretical basis for the proposed reaction mechanism for the cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxides. Thus, a novel heterogeneous catalyst with biomass resource such as cellulose nanofibers have been developed in this paper, which provides a greener way for CO2 conversion to fine chemicals. coredata.dc:description: For the simultaneous attainment of the utilization of renewable biomass resources and the mitigation of greenhouse effects, it is very promising to develop a green, recyclable, and highly efficient heterogeneous catalyst for the synthesis of cyclic carbonates by CO2 cycloaddition reaction with epoxides. Herein, novel cellulose nanofibers (CNF) supported (Salen)Cr(Ⅲ) complex was effectively synthesized for the aforementioned reaction. The cellulose nanofibers (CNF) were firstly modified with (3-aminopropyl) triethoxysilane (APTES), and then its Schiff base with salicylaldehyde was synthesized, which further subjected to coordination treatment with chromium chloride to form a novel heterogeneous catalyst, labelled as CNF-(Salen)Cr(Ⅲ). The catalytic performance of the catalysts shown that CNF-(Salen)Cr(Ⅲ) and co-catalyst TBAB can synergistically catalyze the cycloaddition of CO2 with epichlorohydrin (ECH) at mild reaction conditions, and the yield of chloropropene carbonate (CPC) reached up to 97.8% with high selectivity. The CNF-(Salen)Cr(Ⅲ) complex maintained high catalytic activity after six cycles of repeated runs and has acceptable catalytic effect on other series of epoxies. Based on density functional theory (DFT) calculations, a reaction mechanism including adsorption activation of epoxides, epoxides ring opening, CO2 insertion, and the formation of cyclic carbonate, was proposed for the CNF-(Salen)Cr(Ⅲ) complex catalyzed cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxides.
coredata.dc:title: Cellulose nanofibers (CNF) supported (Salen)Cr(III) composite as an efficient heterogeneous catalyst for CO2 cycloaddition
